metadata.title: Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES)
description: Several different names and abbreviations are used to refer to electrical stimulation,(1,9) including the following: –NMES – neuromuscular electrical stimulation – activation of muscle through electrical stimulation of the intact peripheral nerve -NMES involves the external control of weak or paralyzed muscles by electrical stimulation. The goal of this external activation is to reduce impairment and improve voluntary function -During NMES, pulsed current is applied through an electrode to the motor point of innervated muscles to produce muscle contractions -The characteristics of the applied current can be adjusted according to the presenting condition and therapeutic goals -It can be used for muscle strengthening, increasing ROM, and facilitating muscle contractions for enhancing motor control and improving function (see Indications and Guidelines for use , below) -A unique feature of NMES is that it elicits recruitment of motor neurons that is less orderly than in voluntary exercise, favoring activation of large, type II, higher-force-producing  motor units at relatively low levels of stimulation(40) -In voluntary exercise,a greater intensity is required to activate these larger motor units(45) –FES – functional electrical stimulation – use of electrical stimulation of the peripheral nervous system to activate muscles to assist in functional activities (might also be referred to as FNS – functional neuromuscular stimulation). FES is a type of NMES. For more information about FES, please see  Clinical Review…Functional Electrical Stimulation: Adults  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708953 -When the goal of the stimulation is to produce purposeful movements, it is usually referred to as FES. The long-term  management of these movements will require ongoing electrical stimulation(1) –ES – electrical stimulation –EMS – electrical muscle stimulation – use of electrical stimulation to activate muscles directly, without activation of the peripheral nerve (e.g., to activate denervated muscle).EMS parameters are significantly different than for NMES –TENS – transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation – use of electrical stimulation for the relief or management of pain. Please see  Clinical Review…Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS): Adults  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708952 –SES – sensory electrical stimulation – electrical stimulation applied at amplitudes that do not activate muscles, but that do activate sensory fibers.Might elicit reflexes that produce muscle contractions  –EMG-NMES  – neuromuscular stimulation triggered by the electrical activity recorded from an active muscle, or EMG
reimbursement: Clinicians are advised to check with insurance providers before the administration of electrical stimulation. NMES can be billed as directly supervised or unattended. For home use, medical insurance providers might require that the patient rent a stimulator rather than purchase one, and might limit the length of time a patient can keep the rental unit. Reimbursement might depend on chronicity, etiology, and severity of the condition. In many cases, proper documentation of NMES programs and outcomes affects the probability of reimbursement

Coverage will vary by insurance provider. For example, according to United Healthcare (UHC), NMES is medically necessary for the treatment of disuse atrophy if the nerve supply to the muscle is intact and the source of muscle disuse atrophy is not of neurological origin;(51) NMES can be used to treat wrist and finger function and correct/prevent shoulder subluxation in patients with partial paralysis post stroke.(51)UHC considers NMES to be unproven and/or not medically necessary for any other condition(51) Indications for procedure

indications for procedure: To elicit motor responses in innervated muscle(1,56) Muscle conditioning –Strength –Endurance Maintain or increase ROM/contracture reduction(56) Facilitation and re-education  of voluntary motor function –After CNS injury or disease –Decreased muscle activation due to a musculoskeletal injury or condition -NMES used to elicit an isometric contraction can supplement or temporarily replace voluntary exercise at a time when the patient is unlikely to tolerate active movement (e.g., pain due to injury or postoperative pain)(43) -Arthrogenic muscle inhibition (AMI)(43,57) -A neural process that inhibits full activation of muscles surrounding a joint after injury or surgery (e.g., quadriceps with knee joint injury/surgery) -The effectiveness of NMES as a disinhibitory modality (intended to improve voluntary activation before volitional exercise) has not been established. Evidence suggests that NMES does not improve voluntary activation in quadriceps in patients with orthopedic knee conditions(57) Orthoses substitution (FES) –Activation of muscle for purposeful movement –Activation of muscle to manage joint deformity Edema management Spasticity and muscle spasm management(56,58)
To provide somatosensory feedback where sensation is diminished(1,2,3,4,5)

electrodes: Description(1)–An electrode should provide a low impedance interface between the skin and the stimulator–The electrode system includes the electrode plus the conducting medium and fixation used to maintain contact–Commercially available electrodes include products that contain conducting gel and an adhesive – manufacturers’guidelines should be followed–For the quadriceps, electrodes should be large and well adapted to the patient’s thigh to minimize current density andmaximize comfort for patients(70)

Placement–Electrode placement depends on the patient and treatment goals–The depth of the tissue to be stimulated must be considered. If electrodes are placed close together, most of the currentpasses through surface tissue, whereas electrodes placed farther apart tend to stimulate deeper tissue(1)–If a high degree of specificity is required, the precise motor point should be identified–The most common electrode configuration is bipolar
stimulation parameters ,: Pulsed current is applied. A pulse is an isolated electrical event separated by a finite period from the next event. It can bedescribed in terms of its amplitude, duration, or waveform. Generally, a train of pulses is applied, followed by a period inwhich no stimulus is applied. A train of pulses can be described in terms of its repetition rate, on time, and off time

Amplitude and duration–The amplitude, or intensity of the current pulse, combined with its duration must be adequate to meet the threshold of thestimulated tissue–The relationship between stimulus amplitude and duration is reciprocal, as is illustrated in a strength-duration curve–A short pulse duration requires a much higher stimulus amplitude to be effective than a longer pulse, and vice versa–One of the differences found between stimulators is the pulse duration that is available. Some devices have fixed pulsedurations and some have a limited range of durations (e.g., 20–500  µs(56))–Although short pulse durations are thought less likely to recruit nociceptors, the results of a study in the United Statescomparing maximum tolerated muscle torques produced by different pulse durations support the use of a medium pulseduration rather than a short pulse duration to produce maximum torque(6)-The goal for strengthening with NMES is to produce the highest forces possible to produce the largest and most rapidstrength gains-Participants in this study tolerated significantly greater muscle torques produced by stimulation with 200 μs pulsedurations than with 50 μs pulse durations–An observational substudy of an RCT conducted in the United States that included only patients who received NMESfound that higher electrical intensities are associated with greater quadriceps muscle strength and activation after totalknee arthroplasty (TKA)(40)

Ramp times(9)–If the amplitude of the pulse train is increased slowly, the number of excited nerve fibers can be increased gradually to themaximum setting–The gradual ramp allows a more graded muscle contraction as the muscle fibers are recruited and is usually morecomfortable–Usually, long up and down ramps (greater than 2 seconds) are chosen when a high intensity of stimulation is required orwhen a muscle is sensitive to a rapid stretch (e.g., spasticity)

Frequency – pulse repetition rate(56)–The frequency of the stimulus influences the strength and quality of the evoked contraction, from a single twitch to atetanic contraction–Most clinical applications of NMES call for a tetanic contraction–A frequency between 25 and 50 Hz is usually required to produce tetanic contraction-Researchers of a study in Korea who investigated optimal NMES frequencies for activating deep abdominal stabilizationmuscles concluded that 50 Hz produced stronger muscle contractions than 20 Hz or 80 Hz. The study included 20healthy individuals and utilized ultrasound to measure changes in muscle thickness of the transverse abdominis,obliquus internus, and obliquus externus(54)–Higher frequency can lead to more rapid fatigue. To minimize fatigue, one should aim to produce fused tetany at thelowest rate possible

Waveform(45)–The stimulus waveform affects the effectiveness and comfort–The waveform typically used for NMES is square or rectangular with abrupt onset and offset–Nerve accommodation is less likely to occur with abrupt onset

On-off  time(45)–On-off  cycling allows NMES to be used over extended periods of time while maintaining quality muscle contractions–During the on time, the stimulator delivers a train of pulses of the specified amplitude, duration, and frequency–The motor response will be maintained for the duration of the train of pulses (on time)–The stimulated muscle is allowed to rest and recover during the off-time–Insufficient off-time  can lead to rapid fatigue
treatment frequency and duration: Depends on therapeutic goal – can range from one treatment session to long-term  use
modulation of parameters: The choice of which parameters to vary must be considered within the context of treatment goals(7)
The parameters that are most commonly adjusted to maximize torque are pulse amplitude, duration, and frequency(8)
On-off  time is often adjusted to minimize fatigue
To obtain a strength training effect high contractile forces are needed, which requires high-frequency  andhigh-intensity stimulation, and therefore a long off-time  to avoid fatigue
The rate of fatigue during application of electrical stimulation to skeletal muscle is much faster than during volitionalcontractions(7)Contraindications/Precautions to the procedure
contraindications: Pacemaker–There are no specific international policies or guidelines about the use of NMES in patients with cardiac rhythm devices,and no consensus in the literature(59)–Presence of a cardiac demand pacemaker is an absolute contraindication because current might interfere with theelectronics of the pacemaker. NMES might be used with other pacemakers with great caution(1,9)–In 2017 authors of a systematic review of the safety of electrical stimulation in patients with pacemakers and implantablecardioverter defibrillators concluded that a large, long-term,  and intervention-specific  safety study is needed to obtain anaccurate estimate of the risk of electromagnetic interference; and until such a study is conducted, electrical stimulationshould be used with caution in patients with pacemakers and implanted cardioverter defibrillators(60)
Stimulation immediately over carotid sinus nerves(9)
Malignancies in the area to be treated(9)
Any time active exercise is contraindicated, NMES is also contraindicated(1)–e.g., immobilized tendon repairs
precautions: Conditions that might be affected by muscle contractions – patients must be evaluated for the appropriateness of activeexercise(1)–Cardiac arrhythmia–Congestive heart failure (CHF)–Recent myocardial infarction (MI)–Elevated blood pressure–Thrombophlebitis–In a South Korean study, investigators examining the effect of NMES on heart rate variability (HRV) found that afterNMES HR and HRV increased slightly, but the increases were not significant(46)-Quadriceps muscles were stimulated with NMES in 10 healthy subjects-Researchers suggest that NMES does not induce cardiac stress via disruption of the autonomic nervous system balanceand can be used safely
Altered or absent sensation is not a contraindication but indicates the need for extra caution(56)–A lack of patient feedback significantly increases the risk of adverse reactions

Pregnancy – theoretical risks have been identified(1)–First trimester – the effect of electrical current during tissue differentiation is unknown.There have been no studiesidentifying risk associated with NMES in the first trimester–Third trimester – the risk of triggering premature contractions has not been studied

Protruding metal (e.g., surgical staples, external fixation)–Current will concentrate at metal, which will cause discomfort if sensation is intact. There is a danger of tissue damage,especially if sensation is not intact(1)
Incision – stimulation should not put stress on an incision(1)
Osteoporosis –forces  generated by NMES might cause pathologic fractures of osteoporotic bones(9)
ROM limitations imposed by joint instability or surgical reconstruction(1)
Allergic reactions to electrodes or conduction medium(1)
Might cause skin irritation or electrical burns(56)

Obesity(1,9)–In placing stimulating electrodes, the depth of the target tissue and composition of intervening tissues must be considered.In obesity, the distance between the electrode and the target muscle is increased, and fat is a poor conductor of electricity.The increased current needed to get the desired muscle response can be too painful to tolerate
Potential for autonomic dysreflexia with stimulation of patients with cervical or high thoracic spinal cord injury (SCI)(1) –can elicit unregulated sympathetic activity
Cognitively impaired, agitated, or confused patients(9)

Pediatric patients(45)–Acceptance and tolerance of NMES might be lower in children than adults–Special considerations include fear and apprehension of electricity for both child and parent–Parental consent should be obtained

History of seizures(9)–Guidelines to follow if the patient is having a seizure:-Stay calm-Protect the patient from harm (eliminate dangerous objects, make sure the patient is on a safe surface, lower to the floor)-Stay with the patient-Do not hold down the extremities-Release restrictive clothing-Do not place anything in the patient’s mouth-Try to roll the patient onto his or her side-If possible, place a pillow under the patient’s head-Time the seizure-In the rare circumstance that the patient does not resume normal breathing, begin rescue breathing
Proximity to diathermy–NMES electrodes might pick up electromagnetic radiation from diathermy devices used within approximately 15 feet(9)
Implanted stimulators such as phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators(9)–Current could interfere with their function – consult the patient’s physician before applying NMES

contraindications precautions to examina: Examination procedures are dependent on the underlying condition. The information listed below is meant to serve as a guide/overview. Clinicians should supplement or modify the recommendations listed below as indicated and appropriate for the unique circumstances of the patient. Follow any specific guidelines/order and any precautions or restrictions from the referring physician, and if modifications are indicated, discuss with the referring physician

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -What is the reason for a referral? Date of injury or surgery? -Have there been any complications since the onset of symptoms?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management will vary depending on specific condition. Establish whether the patient is medically stable before initiating NMES program. Document prior medical management, especially in instances in which NMES is indicated when conventional management has failed (e.g., wound healing)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications were prescribed and whether they are taken and effective. With conditions that might be treated with NMES, patients might be medicated for spasticity, depression, seizures, and/or pain
diagnostic tests completed: If presenting condition results from CNS insult (e.g., stroke, head injury), patients might have numerous diagnostic tests including, but not limited to, the following:
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has previously received NMES and with what results. What other occupational or physical therapy has patient received for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms are aggravated orAre there any specific factors that affect such variables as pain or spasticity?
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if the pain is present now and how much); use an Oucher scale for Pediatrics;and FLACC or another nonverbal scale for nonverbal patients
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (AM, mid-day, PM, night); also, document changes in symptoms due to external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that may need a referral to a physician (dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Depending on the condition being treated, thorough documentation of respiratory status might be important. NMES might be used in an acute setting when patients are on supplemental oxygen, or mechanical ventilator, or to treat patients with dyspnea Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient have a previous history of the condition being treated?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, seizures, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, cognitive impairments, and orthopedic disorders Does the patient have a pacemaker?
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he/she might be experiencing. In neurological conditions such as stroke and SCI, NMES might be applicable for several symptoms, and it is necessary to document and prioritize symptoms to be treated

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient work or attend school? If so, describe the job/school setting. What does the job require? Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document limitations with self-care, home management, work, and community/leisure. Does the patient drive?
social and occupational history.living environment: Number of stairs and floors in the home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home and if any modifications are necessary

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Calculate BMI. Perform repeated circumferential measures of extremity if using NMES to treat edema
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient require assistive or adaptive devices? If so, a complete assessment of patient’s functional abilities (especially gait) using the assistive or adaptive device is required. This is essential when comparing functional abilities using electrical stimulation to replace traditional mechanical orthoses (e.g., dorsiflexion assist)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Thorough assessment of balance using a standardized balance measure (e.g., Berg Balance Scale [BBS], Timed Up and Go [TUG] test) might be indicated if stimulation is to be used for addressing balance(11)
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Use FIM or TUG test for objective measurement of functional mobility
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Complete a thorough gait assessment if indicated by reason for referral. Note any asymmetry or gait abnormality. Use the Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) or Tinetti Performance Oriented Mobility Assessment for objective measurementAssess joint integrity and mobility as indicated by reason for referral. Since NMES can take a joint through greater range than can be obtained voluntarily, identify ROM limitations imposed by joint instability, muscle contractures, or surgical procedures. Assess the potential for hyperextension or excessive compression of a joint in selecting stimulus intensityA thorough assessment of voluntary motor control using an appropriate scale (e.g., Fugl-Meyer)  is indicated before use of NMES for facilitation and re-education  of motor function. Assess muscle tone as indicated using the Modified Ashworth Scale. Coordination and fine motor dexterity might need to be assessed as indicated
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Complete a thorough strength assessment with a focus on the area to be stimulated. It is also important to document the strength of contraction elicited by stimulation. Use a handheld dynamometer or pinchometers to assess hand strength; do not use MMT in the presence of abnormal tone or coordinationAssess as indicated for children with neurological involvement and/or developmental delay
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess bilateral upper and lower extremity active and passive ROM, with particular attention to the area where NMES is to be applied if using NMES for maintenance of range or contracture reduction
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexes, primitive reflexes (e.g., Babinski) and reactions as indicated. Note any asymmetry or abnormal responseComplete standardized testing of ADLs as indicated to document
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assessment of cognition, including memory and problem solving, is indicated for establishing the patient’s ability to learn to use this device independently in a home program. Patients who are agitated or extremely confused (e.g., traumatic brain injury) are not NMES candidates since the sensory input might further add to their confusion(10)

contraindications precautions: Modifications of one or more parameters including frequency, current amplitude, pulse duration,and waveform might be necessary to decrease discomfort. No optimal settings have been identified(6)
Unlike volitional contraction, with NMES synchronous recruitment of motor units occurs and once motor units are recruited they continue to fire until the stimulus ends
Also unlike volitional contraction, the larger, fatigable motor units (type II) are the first to be recruited ›Diagnosis/need for the procedure
A specific term that refers to symmetrical, generalized muscle weakness that develops after the onset of critical illness without other identifiable causes
Six trials of NMES used in patients in the ICU have demonstrated mixed but promising results. The need for additional research, especially to determine optimal parameters, has been identified
other: This treatment might be used with patients who are at risk for falls; if inpatient, follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post-fall  prevention instructions at the bedside. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

This treatment might be used with patients who are at risk for autonomic dysreflexia. Monitor for signs and symptoms of autonomic dysreflexia if using with patients who have high thoracic or cervical spinal cord injuries; NMES might intensely activate sensory systems, which can provide unregulated drive to the sympathetic nervous system. Discontinue stimulation and seek emergent medical care at signs of excessive sympathetic activity (e.g., sweating, headache, bradycardia, elevated blood pressure, piloerection).  Please see  Clinical Review…Autonomic Dysreflexia in Adults  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708491

This treatment might be used with patients who are at risk for aspiration. Patients being treated for dysphagia might have choking/aspiration precautions as part of their care/support plan. Precautions might include proper positioning, especially during mealtimes

The muscle force that can be generated by NMES is limited by patient discomfort and is typically no more than 80% of the maximum force that can be produced voluntarily. Recruitment of nociceptors has been assumed to contribute to the limited muscle forces that patients can tolerate during NMES(6)
Fatigue can be a major problem with the use of NMES(45,47)
Orthopedic injury/surgery resulting in muscle weakness or inability to activate muscle(56)

prognosis: Long-term  effectiveness following discontinuation of NMES is questionable(47)

There are reports of the benefits of NMES waning following the withdrawal of stimulation in various applications (e.g., spasticity reduction in cerebral palsy, hand function after stroke, shoulder subluxation)(47)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: NMES for dysphagia is referred typically to speech therapy as available. Referral might be made to occupational therapy for upper extremity NMES or FES(14)
other considerations: In 2013, authors of a systematic review found that short-term application (5 minutes or less) of cryotherapy before use of NMES can improve patient tolerance of the strong contractions required for strengthening; however, longer applications of cryotherapy (20 minutes or more) can affect the muscle’s ability to produce force(44)
In a 2015 systematic review,evidence to date was not found to support the use of NMES in thromboprophylaxis, although NMES increases venous blood flow(52)
treatment summary: See  Description  ,  Indications of procedure   and  Guidelines for the use of procedure  above –Orthopedic -The quadriceps femoris is the most frequently stimulated muscle group(70) -In a systematic review and meta-analysis  of RCTs to determine whether NMES is effective to strengthen the quadriceps femoris, researchers suggest that NMES is of some benefit compared with doing no exercise, but that volitional exercises appear to be as or more effective in most situations(15) -Thirty-five  trials were included and evaluated -A distinction was made between impaired (post injury or surgery) and unimpaired quadriceps -In situations in which volitional muscle training is difficult or compliance is low (i.e., within-cast,  immobilization), NMES might be preferred -The main outcome measure was muscle torque -Interpretation of the results, including clinical applicability, was limited by methodological weaknesses in the clinical trials and heterogeneous data  -Authors of a meta-analysis  of studies evaluating the effectiveness of NMES after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) report that NMES resulted in slightly better functional recovery compared to conventional rehabilitation in the early postoperative period but that there is no difference in the medium-term  and long-term  postoperative periods(63) -Six studies, with a total of 496 participants, were included -All studies compared a group receiving NMES to a control group that followed a rehabilitation protocol. Outcome measures included the TUG test, stair climbing test, and walk tests -Patients in the group receiving NMES had better scores in the first postoperative weeks, but the benefits of NMES diminished overtime -The authors concluded that NMES after TKA is easy and safe to apply, and results in faster functional recovery in the immediate postoperative period -The heterogeneity of rehabilitation protocols, including NMES settings and the start time, duration, and frequency of treatment, was a limiting factor in the meta-analysis -In a meta-analysis  completed in 2018, researchers found that patients receiving NMES after TKA had improved scores on the TUG, stair climbing test, and 6MWTrelative to patients not receiving NMES(74) -Benefits from NMES were greatest in the early postoperative stages of recovery.There was no difference between groups in medium-  to long-term stages -Researchers who conducted a study in the United States found that NMES might be useful to treat muscle atrophy and weakness in patients with RA(18) -NMES and a volitional exercise training protocol were evaluated for quadriceps strengthening in patients with RA in a multiple-patient  case report -Patients who completed the protocol increased their lean muscle mass, muscle strength, and physical function -Neither the effects of NMES alone nor those of exercise alone were compared to the effects of combining NMES with exercise -Protocol was not well-tolerated  or adhered to by some patients with RA -An NMES training protocol can be a useful treatment adjunct following anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) repair(16,17) -Investigators in a prospective randomized clinical trial conducted in the United States of electrical stimulation for quadriceps strengthening and functional recovery after ACL reconstruction found that there was greater quadriceps strength recovery in patients who received high-intensity  electrical stimulation versus patients who received only low-intensity electrical stimulation or volitional exercise(16) -Authors of an RCT conducted in the United States (N = 43) examined the effectiveness of a modified NMES protocol in addition to standard rehabilitation(17) -NMES was applied with the patients lying supine with the knees fully extended -The NMES group demonstrated greater quadriceps strength than the control group after 12 weeks of treatment -The effectiveness of NMES appears proportional to the dose; the larger the dose, the greater the therapeutic effects.(48)In a study conducted in the United States, researchers identified factors that contribute to the ability of patients with RA to tolerate high doses of NMES(48) -Each participant (n = 40) had a diagnosis of RA and participants received 2 sessions of NMES to the quadriceps -The dose was calculated as the amount of torque resulting from the application of NMES and this value was compared to the torque measured from a maximal voluntary isometric contraction -Correlations between NMES and disability, pain coping strategies, pain acceptance, sense of mastery or control, anxiety, and depression were investigated. Outcome measures included the following: -Health Assessment Questionnaire Disability Index (HAQ-DI) -Coping Strategies Questionnaire (CSQ) -Chronic Pain Acceptance Questionnaire (CPAQ) -Sense of Mastery Scale (SMA) -Center for Epidemiological Studies Short Depression Scale (CESD) -Anxiety Inventory Form (AI) -Disability, catastrophizing, coping self-statements,  and anxiety were predictors of the maximum dose tolerated with NMES -Patients who had lower catastrophizing, evidenced by lower scores on a subset of the CSQ, and lower levels of disability were able to achieve higher doses  -NMES did not improve quadriceps muscle strength and activation in women with radiographic evidence of early knee osteoarthritis in an RCT conducted in the United States(19) -Thirty women with mild-moderate  knee osteoarthritis were included in the study. Participants were randomized into two groups: no treatment or NMES 3 times per week for 4 weeks -Patients with a history of knee surgery or ligamentous knee injury were excluded -NMES targeted the quadriceps muscles; each treatment session included 10 stimulation-induced contractions with the intensity of current set to the maximum tolerated. A target intensity of at least 35% of the maximum voluntary isometric contraction was encouraged -Similar protocols have been used for post anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction and TKA intervention and have a history of effectiveness for these populations. It is possible the dosage was insufficient for improving quadriceps strength and activation in early knee osteoarthritis. The dose-response  relationship is not determined in this population -Investigators in Switzerland report that NMES of the intrinsic foot muscles enhances their function as medial longitudinal arch stabilizers and can be used to alter foot plantar pressure patterns and improve dynamic control to reduce breakdown(50) -NMES treatment is typically performed over a 3 to 5 week period and includes an average of 9 to 12 sessions with a gradual progression of active modeling in combination with functional integration activities (e.g., single limb squatting) -Authors of an RCT published in 2019 concluded that NMES was effective in reducing edema post ankle sprain (grade I and II), as measured by fluid displacement(75) -The control group consisted of patients receiving the current standard of care for ankle sprain and the intervention group received NMES as an adjunct to the current standard of care -There were no between-group  differencesin figure 8 measurement, pain scores, or functional scores -Researchers of a 2019 systematic review found that NMES is effective in various rehabilitation settings and patient groups to reduce edema(76) -Given the limited number of trials available (8 total), the researchers advocated for further trials to reinforce these findings –Stroke -NMES might be used to enable active practice when the severity of motor and sensory deficits limits or prevents active practice. Following a stroke, NMES has been reported to improve ROMand force production and to reduce hypertonicity.(78)NMES might be useful for reducing shoulder subluxation and pain and there is also evidence that NMES facilitates motor relearning of the upper and lower extremities(20) -Authors of a meta-analysis  of studies evaluating the effectiveness of NMES for management of shoulder subluxation post-stroke  found a beneficial effect in individuals with acute and subacute stroke, but no significant benefits for individuals with chronic stroke(64) -The effectiveness of short (1 hour or less) and long (greater than 1 hour) daily treatment durations was examined -Eleven studies were included with a total of 432 participants -In patients with acute and subacute stroke, there was a significant treatment effect for reduction of subluxation with short or long daily treatment durations -Effective parameters included frequency of 10–36  pps, pulse duration 200–250  µs, and treatment 3 to 7 times per week for 4 to 8 weeks -There was no significant treatment effect for patients with chronic stroke (greater than 6 months) -There was no significant treatment effect on arm function or shoulder pain -NMES during task-oriented  exercise can be used to produce or augment contractions in paretic muscles(20,21) -EMG triggered NMES is produced when an individual voluntarily attempts to move and the EMG corresponds by triggering the NMES. For example, as poststroke patients attempt to extend their wrist and fingers, the EMG-triggered stimulation assists the movement, and full extension is experienced -In a 2000 RCT in the United States (N = 11), investigators found that EMG-triggered  NMES to the wrist and finger extensors of individuals with chronic hemiparesis due to stroke resulted in significant improvements in grasping small objects and sustaining contractions(22) -In 2008, a systematic review of RCTs of EMG-triggered  neuromuscular stimulation of the wrist and finger extensors after stroke found no statistically significant differences compared to usual care(23)  -Eight studies (N = 157) met criteria for meta-analysis -Meta-analysis  did not find significant effect sizes in sustained contraction, reaction time, or dexterity -Most of the studies were restricted to chronic or subacute phases after stroke – only one was within 3 weeks poststroke -These findings were incongruous with those of a 2004 meta-analysis  which found a significant overall effect of EMG-triggered  NMES on the recovery of arm/hand function after stroke(51) -One difference was that nonrandomized controlled trials were included in the 2004 study(51) -EMG-triggered  NMES as an adjunct to constraint-induced  movement therapy (CIMT) was reported to be feasible and beneficial in a casestudy in the United States(24) -Individuals not capable of extending their wrists and fingers are excluded from CIMT protocols -Use of EMG-triggered  NMES enabled clients to follow the CIMT protocol -EMG-triggered  NMES to the affected tibialis anterior muscle can increase active ROM and improve aspects of balance and gait, accordingto authors of a case study conducted in the United States(11) -In a single subject 16 months poststroke, the impact of low-dose,  EMG-triggered  stimulation on gait and balance was evaluated -Improvements in active ankle dorsiflexion and plantarflexion and in BBS score were seen at a relatively low dose of treatment (20 minutes/day for 4 weeks) -Researchers in China found that use of an electromyographic bridge (EMGB) augmented the recovery of volitional wrist and finger motion in post-stroke  patients better than cyclic NMES did(65) -EMGB differs from EMG-triggered  NMES in that the EMG is recorded from the contralateral arm.
